page.title: Timeline of the Virginia Tech shooting

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Virginia Tech massacre}} This '''timeline of events from the [[Virginia Tech shooting]]''' lists times in [[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Daylight Time]] ([[UTC-4]]).
The official timeline was compiled by TriData Corp, a division of defense contractor [[System Planning Corp.]], for use by the eight-member panel appointed by [[Virginia Governor]] [[Timothy M. Kaine]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/24/AR2007042402267.html |title=State Taps Firm That Handled Probe of Columbine Shootings |first=Bill |last=Turque |date=April 25, 2007 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>[http://www.governor.virginia.gov/TempContent/techPanelReport.cfm?hpid=topnews Official Site of the Governor of Virginia<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Background==
===2003=== * [[Seung-Hui Cho]] graduated from [[Westfield High School (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Westfield High School]] in [[Chantilly, Virginia|Chantilly]], [[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax County]], [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/113874 |title=Killer's troubles began long ago |agency=Associated Press |date=April 20, 2007 |newspaper=The Roanoke Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120911175655/http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/113874 |archivedate=September 11, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===2004=== '''Monday, January 19''' * Cho started trading on [[eBay]] with ID "blazers5505".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070428/ap_on_re_us/virginia_tech_why_2 |title=Whys of rampage elude investigators |first=Allen G. |last=Breed |date=April 27, 2007}}</ref>
===2005=== '''Fall''' * Andy Koch, Cho's suitemate, took Cho out to some parties at the start of the fall semester in 2005. At one party, Cho got "tipsy" enough that he opened up and began talking about his virtual love life. He said he had an imaginary girlfriend named Jelly, and that she was "a supermodel that lived in space." Jelly had a nickname for Cho—Spanky.<ref name=Breed>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/110/story/566897.html |title=Same suite, different planet : Ex-suitemate reflects on Cho's actions |first=Allen G. |last=Breed |first2=Chris |last2=Kahn |date=April 23, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * Andy Koch along with John Eide snooped in Cho's belongings and "found nothing more threatening than a [[pocket knife]]."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18248298/site/newsweek/page/9/ |title=Special Report: Tragedy at Virginia Tech, page 9 |first=Evan |last=Thomas |date=April 30, 2007}}</ref>
'''Fall poetry class''' * Professor [[Nikki Giovanni]] requested that Cho either change the sinister content of his poems or drop the class. Cho responded, "You can't make me."<ref name=Evans>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18248298/site/newsweek/page/3/ |title=Making of a Massacre |first=Evan |last=Thomas |date=April 30, 2007}}</ref>
'''Removed from poetry class''' * [[Lucinda Roy]], co-director of the creative writing program removed Cho from Professor Giovanni's class and tutored him one-on-one. When Cho refused to go to counseling, Roy notified the Division of Student Affairs, the Cook Counseling Center, the Schiffert Health Center, the Virginia Tech police and the College of Liberal Arts and Human Sciences.<ref name=Evans/>
'''Fall writing class''' * Professor [[Lisa Norris]], who had Cho in her class, alerted the associate dean of students, Mary Ann Lewis, who could find "no mention of mental health issues or police reports" on Cho.<ref name=Evans/>
'''Sunday, November 27''' * A female student filed a report with the Virginia Tech campus police indicating that Cho had made "annoying" contact with her on the internet,<ref name=Breed/> by phone and in person. The investigating officer referred Cho to the school's disciplinary system, the office of judicial affairs,<ref name=seuhui>{{cite news |url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/070418/1/47wyx.html |title=Virginia gunman was accused of stalking: police |date=April 18, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> which is separate from the police department.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1612226,00.html |title=Were Cho's Danger Signs Missed? |first=John |last=Cloud |date=April 18, 2007 | work=Time}}</ref>
'''Monday, December 12''' * Another female student, a friend of Andy Koch,<ref name=Breed/> filed a report with the Virginia Tech campus police complaining of "disturbing" instant messages from Cho. She requested that Cho "have no further contact with her."<ref name=seuhui/><ref name=Dedman>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18175525/ |title=Cho's words, actions fit school shooting pattern |first=Bill |last=Dedman |author-link=Bill Dedman |date=April 18, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walb.com/Global/story.asp?S=6390701&nav=menu37_2_1_12 |title=Shooter sent "package" to NBC between murders |accessdate=April 16, 2008 |date=April 20, 2007 |publisher=WALB.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117024635/http://www.walb.com/Global/story.asp?S=6390701&nav=menu37_2_1_12 |archivedate=November 17, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
'''Tuesday, December 13''' * Virginia Tech campus police notified Cho that he was to have no further contact with the female student. * After Virginia Tech campus police left, Andy Koch, Cho's roommate, received an instant message from Cho stating, "I might as well kill myself now."<ref name=Breed/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/113495 |title=Interview transcript with shooter's former roommates |date=April 18, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130208173715/http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/113495 |archivedate=February 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * In response to receiving the instant message from Cho, ''Andy Koch'', Cho's roommate, notified the resident advisor and phoned ''his'' father.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/21/AR2007042101223_2.html |title='Looking Back . . . We Should Have Done Something' |first=Michael E. |last=Ruane |date=April 22, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Koch and his father alerted [[Virginia Tech]] campus police that Cho had sent Koch a suicidal instant message. * Virginia Tech campus police took Cho off campus to a voluntary counseling evaluation at New River Community Services,<ref name=Dedman/> where he was examined by Kathy Goodbey. Goodbey determined that he was "mentally ill and in need of hospitalization."<ref name=Schulte>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/06/AR2007050601403.html |title=Cho Didn't Get Court-Ordered Treatment |first=Brigid |last=Schulte |first2=Chris L. |last2=Jenkins |date=May 7, 2007 |accessdate=May 10, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> * Cho's paperwork, declaring Cho "an imminent danger to self or others," was sent to court. * Cho was transported to Carilion St. Albans [[Psychiatric Hospital]] where [[psychologist]] Roy Crouse determined that Cho "is mentally ill; that he does not present an imminent danger to (himself/others), or is not substantially unable to care for himself, as a result of mental illness; and that he does not require involuntary hospitalization."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.governor.virginia.gov/tempcontent/techPanelReport-docs/8%20CHAPTER%20IV%20LIFE%20AND%20MENTAL%20HEALTH%20HISTORY%20OF%20CHOpdf.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=July 20, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812220722/http://www.governor.virginia.gov/TempContent/techPanelReport-docs/8%20CHAPTER%20IV%20LIFE%20AND%20MENTAL%20HEALTH%20HISTORY%20OF%20CHOpdf.pdf |archive-date=August 12, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
'''Wednesday, December 14''' * Cho was released from Carilion St. Albans [[Psychiatric Hospital]] after his examination by Roy Crouse.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-shooter19apr19,0,2668915.story?coll=la-home-headlines |title=Gunman had presented an 'imminent danger' in 2005 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=April 19, 2007 |first=''Part |last=Two'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070420165156/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-shooter19apr19,0,2668915.story?coll=la-home-headlines |archivedate=April 20, 2007 }}</ref> * Cho's paperwork was sent to special Justice Paul M. Barnett, who certified the finding and ordered follow-up treatment.<ref name=DetentionOrder>{{cite news |url=https://media.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/metro/pdf/cho_mentalhealth.pdf |title=FOIA detention order |date=April 20, 2007 |format=PDF | work=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=3052278&page=1 |title=Va. Tech Killer Ruled Mentally Ill by Court; Let Go After Hospital Visit | publisher=ABC News |accessdate=April 19, 2007 |date=April 18, 2007}}</ref> * Neither the court, the university nor community services officials followed up on the judge's order, according to dozens of interviews. Cho never got the treatment, according to authorities who have seen his medical files.<ref name=Schulte/>
===2006=== '''Fall''' * Cho enrolled in Professor Brent Stevens's English 3984 class, "Special Studies: Contemporary Horror. - 'not for the faint of heart' ." In that class he analyzed ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'' and explored in papers and a "fear journal" how "horror has become a masochistic pleasure."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.townhall.com/columnists/MaryGrabar/2007/04/24/the_making_of_a_mass_murderer--_in_english_class |title=The making of a mass murderer--In english class |first=Mary |last=Grabar |date=April 24, 2007}}</ref> Cho later sold his textbooks on [[eBay]]-affiliated site [[half.com]]. The textbooks that were sold included ''[[Men, Women, and Chainsaws]]'' by [[Carol J. Clover]], a book that explores gender in the modern horror film. Others include ''The Best of [[H. P. Lovecraft]]: Bloodcurdling Tales of Horror and the Macabre''; and ''The Female of the Species: Tales of Mystery and Suspense'' by [[Joyce Carol Oates]] - a book in which the publisher writes: "In these and other gripping and disturbing tales, women are confronted by the evil around them and surprised by the evil they find within themselves."<ref>{{cite news | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/22/AR2007042200537_2.html | title =Internet Key in Probe of Va. Tech Gunman |first=Adam |last=Geller |first2=Chris |last2=Kahn |first3=Kristen |last3=Gelineau |first4=Allen G. |last4=Breed |date=April 22, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/21/AR2007042100200_2.html |title=Va. Tech Probe Focuses on Computer Use |first=Adam |last=Geller |first2=Chris |last2=Kahn |date=April 21, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
===2007=== '''Friday, February 2''' * Cho ordered a handgun online. He purchased the [[.22 Long Rifle|.22 caliber]] [[Walther P22]] on the Internet from [[TGSCOM]], Inc.<ref name=HadGuns>{{cite news|url=http://www.wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6388845&nav=S6aK|title=Shooter had guns more than 1 month before Va. shootings|accessdate=April 18, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114043119/http://www.wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6388845&nav=S6aK|archivedate=November 14, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=Kaine>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/19/AR2007041900830_2.html |title=Kaine Gives Panel Latitude to Probe Campus Killings |accessdate=April 20, 2007 |newspaper=The Washington Post |first1=Bill |last1=Turque |first2=Sari |last2=Horwitz |date=April 20, 2007}}</ref><ref name="gunsource">{{cite web |url=http://www.jsonline.com/watch/?watch=1&date=4/19/2007&id=22284 |title=Va. Tech gun bought from state Web firm |date=April 19, 2007 |access-date=April 19, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929141415/http://www.jsonline.com/watch/?watch=1&date=4%2F19%2F2007&id=22284 |archive-date=September 29, 2007 |dead-url=yes}}</ref>
'''Friday, February 9''' * Cho picked up the [[.22 Long Rifle|.22 caliber]] [[Walther P22]] from J-N-D Pawnbrokers [[pawnshop]] in [[Blacksburg, Virginia]]<ref name=HadGuns/><ref name=Kaine/> across the street from the school.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18248298/site/newsweek/page/5/ |title=Making of a Massacre |first=Evan |last=Thomas |date=April 30, 2007}}</ref>
'''March''' * Cho stayed in a [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]] motel and hired a dancer, Chastity Frye, for a one-hour performance.<ref>{{cite news |url =http://abcnews.go.com/US/VATech/story?id=3071730&page=1&CMP=OTC-RSSFeeds0312 |title=Report: Cho Hired an Escort Before Rampage |date=April 24, 2007}}</ref>
'''Monday, March 12''' * Cho rented a burgundy [[Kia Motors|Kia]] [[Kia Carnival|Sedona]] van from [[Enterprise Rent-A-Car]] at the [[Roanoke Regional Airport]] that he kept for almost a month. Cho videotaped some of his diatribe in the van.<ref name=KleinfieldRage>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/22/us/22vatech.html?pagewanted=2&ei=5087%0A&em&en=c03fa6dd698cd1dc&ex=1177387200 |title=Before Deadly Rage, a Life Consumed by a Troubling Silence |first=N. R. |last=Kleinfield |date=April 22, 2007 | work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name=Mystery>{{Cite news | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/25/AR2007042500172_pf.html| title = Va. Tech Killer's Motives Pursued: Some Actions During Rampage Still a Mystery |first=Jerry|last=Markon|first2=Sari|last2=Horwitz |date=April 26, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
'''Tuesday, March 13''' * Cho purchased a [[9 mm Luger Parabellum|9 millimeter]] [[Glock 19]] [[handgun]] and a $10 box of 50 9-mm [[Full metal jacket bullet|full metal jacket]] ammunition.<ref name=FirstGun>Elaine Shannon. [http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1611948,00.html "Where Cho Bought His Deadly Weapon."] TIME magazine. Published April 18, 2007. Last accessed April 19, 2007.</ref>
'''Thursday, March 22''' * Cho showed up at the PSS Range, an indoor pistol range in [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]], and spent an hour practicing, buying four ammunition magazines for the [[Glock 19]]. Range employees, investigators later said, remembered a young Asian man videotaping himself inside a van in the parking lot.<ref name=KleinfieldRage/> * Using the handle "blazers5505" on [[eBay]], Cho purchased two 10-round magazines for the [[Walther P22]] from "Bullelk14"<ref>{{cite web |last=Keizer |first=Gregg |url=http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&taxonomyName=security&articleId=9017419&taxonomyId=17&intsrc=kc_top |title=Va. Tech killer bought magazines on eBay, gun online: First firearm purchase took place as early as February |date=April 22, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114114716/http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&taxonomyName=security&articleId=9017419&taxonomyId=17&intsrc=kc_top |archive-date=November 14, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
'''Friday, March 23''' * Cho purchased three additional 10-round magazines from "oneclickshooting", another [[eBay]] seller located in [[Fremont, Nebraska]].<ref>Geller, A. & Kahn, C. (April 22, 2007). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/22/AR2007042200124.html Internet key in probe in Va. Tech gunman.] ''The Washington Post''. Retrieved on April 22, 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/us/AP-Virginia-Tech-Shooting-Internet.html | title=Internet Key in Probe of Va. Tech Gunman |date=April 22, 2007 | work=The New York Times}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
'''Late March, (exact date uncertain)''' * Cho rented a room in another local hotel and was visited by a dancer from an escort service.<ref>Jerry Markon and Sari Horwitz (April 26, 2007) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/25/AR2007042500172.html Va. Tech Killer's Motives Pursued] ''The Washington Post''</ref>
'''Saturday, March 31 (April 7, 8 and 13)''' * Cho purchased additional ammunition and a hunting knife from [[Wal-Mart]].<ref name=KleinfieldRage/><ref name=NYT.Return>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Urbina |first2=Manny |last2=Fernandez |title=University Explains the Return of Troubled Student |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/20/us/20virginia.html?pagewanted=2 |date=April 20, 2007 | work=The New York Times}}</ref>
''' Unknown date''' * Cho purchased additional ammunition magazines from Dick's Sporting Goods and chains from a [[Home Depot]].<ref name=NYT.Return/>
''' Early April (date unknown) ''' * Cho returns the rented minivan to its owner.
'''Sunday, April 8''' * Cho spent the night at the [[Hampton Inn]] in [[Christiansburg, Virginia]], videotaping segments for his [[manifesto]]-like diatribe.<ref name=KleinfieldRage/>
'''Friday, April 13''' [[Image:Norris hall.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Virginia Tech campus#Norris Hall|Norris Hall]], where 30 of the 32 victims had died.]] * Bomb threats to Torgersen, Durham, and Whittemore Halls were called in anonymously. An additional [[bomb threat]], this time to engineering school buildings, was found at the shooting scene at Norris Hall.<ref name=RoaTimes.Bomb>[http://www.roanoke.com/news/nrv/breaking/wb/113294 Shooting victims at Tech massacre named] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120910153714/http://www.roanoke.com/news/nrv/breaking/wb/113294 |date=September 10, 2012 }}, ''The Roanoke Times'', April 17, 2007</ref> A written [[bomb threat]] similar to the ones that were phoned in was found in Suite 2121 of Harper Hall,<ref name=WashPost.Desk>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/18/AR2007041802824.html | work=The Washington Post |title=That Was the Desk I Chose to Die Under | first=David | last=Maraniss |date=April 19, 2007 |accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref> Cho's dormitory room.<ref name=KillerPrep>[http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1611169,00.html] The Va.Tech Gunman: Well Prepared, 23, ''CNN.com'', April 17, 2007.</ref>
'''Saturday, April 14''' * Witnesses saw a "suspicious looking man with a hooded sweatshirt" near the entrance to Norris Hall, and some of the doors chained shut around the same time.<ref name=Rehearsed>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/10/AR2007081001023.html |title=Va. Tech Shooter May Have Rehearsed Attack |first=Jerry |last=Markon |date=August 10, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> '''Sunday, April 15''' * Cho phoned his family in Fairfax County.<ref name=Mystery/>
==Event== [[File:VA Tech massacre aerial photo of referenced locations.jpg|thumb|alt=Building locations depicted in red.|Aerial photo showing location of [[Campus of Virginia Tech#Other residence halls|Harper Hall]] (Cho's dorm), [[Campus of Virginia Tech#Norris Hall|Norris Hall]], [[Campus of Virginia Tech#Ambler Johnston Hall|West Ambler Johnston Hall]], and the Blacksburg, VA, U.S. Post Office.]] '''Monday, April 16''' * 5:00 a.m.: While in Suite 2120 (room 2121) of Harper Hall,<ref name=WashPost.Desk/> Joseph E. "Joe" Aust,[https://web.archive.org/web/20070426060442/http://media.mgnetwork.com/imd/VTShooting/article53.htm] one of Cho's five roommates, noticed that Cho was awake and at his computer.<ref name=KleinfieldRage/> * Around 5:30 a.m.: Karan Grewal, one of Cho's other roommates, noticed Cho, clad in boxer shorts and a T-shirt, brushing his teeth and applying acne cream after Grewal finished an "all-nighter" of study in Room 2121. Grewal did not see Cho after this point.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18248298/site/newsweek/page/6/ Special Report: Tragedy at Virginia Tech - Newsweek National News - MSNBC.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Between 5:30 and 6:00 a.m.: Aust saw Cho return from the bathroom, get dressed, and leave.<ref>[http://media.mgnetwork.com/imd/VTShooting/article53.htm Tragedy in Blacksburg<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426060442/http://media.mgnetwork.com/imd/VTShooting/article53.htm |date=April 26, 2007 }}</ref> * Before 7:00 a.m.: Cho was seen waiting outside an entrance to West Ambler Johnston Hall.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/114655 |title=Police: No motive found |first=Reed |last=Williams |first2=Shawna |last2=Morrison |date=April 26, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120207181056/http://www.roanoke.com/vtshootingaccounts/wb/114655 |archivedate=February 7, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * Before 7:15 a.m.: Emily Hilscher was dropped off at her dormitory by her boyfriend, Karl D. Thornhill.<ref name=Puzzled>{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/04182007/news/nationalnews/police_puzzled_why_co_ed_was_1st_to_die_nationalnews_dan_mangan.htm |title=Police Puzzled why Co-ed was first to die |work=New York Post |first=Dan |last=Mangan |date=April 18, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070421055055/http://www.nypost.com/seven/04182007/news/nationalnews/police_puzzled_why_co_ed_was_1st_to_die_nationalnews_dan_mangan.htm |archivedate=April 21, 2007 }}</ref> * 7:15 a.m.: A [[9-1-1]] emergency call to Virginia Tech campus police reported a shooting at West Ambler Johnston Hall, leaving Ryan Christopher Clark, the resident advisor, dead and Emily Hilscher fatally wounded in Suite 4040,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1613010,00.html | work=Time |title=Witness: The Dormitory Murders |date=April 20, 2007}}</ref> which housed Hilscher.<ref name=WDBJ7.ROA>[http://wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6375238 At least one dead in campus shooting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070419085246/http://www.wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6375238 |date=April 19, 2007 }}, ''WDBJ7 Roanoke.'' April 16, 2007</ref><ref name=CollegeMedia>[http://www.collegemedia.com Front page], ''[[Collegiate Times]],'' April 16, 2007</ref><ref name=VT.Alert>Larry Hincker. "[http://www.vt.edu/campus_alert.php Shooting at Virginia Tech] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418235239/http://www.vt.edu/campus_alert.php |date=April 18, 2007 }}", Virginia Tech bulletin, April 16, 2007.</ref> * Between 7:15 am and 9:01 a.m.: Cho returned to his dormitory room to reload and left a "disturbing note."<ref name=Fox.Motive>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,266500,00.html Virginia Tech Police Still Search for Motive After Identifying Shooter], April 17, 2007</ref> * 7:30 a.m.: Investigators from VT PD and Blacksburg PD arrived. * Between 7:30 am and 8:00 a.m.: Heather Haugh, Emily Hilscher's friend and roommate, arrived to meet her to go to chemistry class together. When she asked about Hilscher, Haugh was questioned by detectives and gave them the information that Hilscher would usually spend weekends with her boyfriend, Karl Thornhill, at his off-campus townhouse. She explained that on Monday mornings Thornhill would drop off Hilscher and go back to [[Radford University]] where he was a student, and that Thornhill was an avid gun user. This led the police to seek him out as a "[[person of interest]]."<ref name=KleinfieldRage/><ref name=Puzzled/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hotair.com/archives/2007/04/17/new-vtech-thread-victims-roommate-debunks-the-jilted-lover-theory/|title=New VTech thread: Victim's roommate debunks the jilted lover theory; Update: Roommates say he stalked classmates, had imaginary girlfriend; Update: "Ismail Ak"? "Ismale Ax"?|work=HotAir.com|accessdate=February 18, 2015}}</ref> * 8:00 a.m.: Classes at Virginia Tech began. * Around 8:00 a.m.: West Ambler Johnston was locked down; a third floor resident assistant notified students of the lockdown. Aimee Kanode, a freshman, stated that police lifted the lockdown shortly before the Norris Hall attacks.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18138327/ Timeline: How deadly shooting unfolded - Massacre at Virginia Tech - MSNBC.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * 8:25 a.m.: Virginia Tech leadership team met to develop a plan on how to notify students of the homicide. Meanwhile, police stopped Karl Thornhill, in a vehicle off-campus and detained him for questioning. * 8:52 a.m.: University President Charles Steger's office is locked down.<ref>{{cite news |first=Zach |last=Crizer |title=Governor hands down revised April 16 report |url=http://www.collegiatetimes.com/stories/14776/updated-governor-hands-down-revised-april-16-report |work=[[Collegiate Times]] |publisher= |date=December 4, 2009 |page=A01 |accessdate=December 4, 2009}}</ref> * 9:00 a.m.: Virginia Tech leadership team was briefed on the latest events in the ongoing dormitory homicide investigation. * 9:01 am: Cho mailed a [[U.S. Postal Service]] express parcel from Blacksburg P.O. to [[NBC]] headquarters in [[New York City]], containing pictures of him holding weapons, a 1,800-word diatribe and a video clip alluding to the coming massacre.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael E. |last=Ruane |first2=Chris L. |last2=Jenkins |title=Gunman Sent Video During Lull In Slaughter |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/18/AR2007041800834.html |work=[[Washington Post]] |publisher= |date=April 19, 2007 |page=A01 |accessdate=April 15, 2008}}</ref> * 9:05 am: [[Jocelyne Couture-Nowak]]'s Intermediate French Class in Norris 211 began.<ref name=Goddard>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-04-21-virginia-tech-goddard_N.htm | work=USA Today |title=Survivor recalls moments leading up to Va. Tech shootings | first=Andrea | last=Stone |date=April 22, 2007 |accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref> * Around 9:05 a.m. to 9:15 a.m.: Cho was seen in Norris Hall, an Engineering building. Using chains (possibly the ones he had purchased at Home Depot), Cho chained the building's entry doors shut from the inside.<ref name=NYT.Return/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/worldnews.html?in_article_id=448955&in_page_id=1811&ct=5 | location=London | work=Daily Mail |title=A lovers' tiff in the dormitory... then the university killer began his rampage |date=April 17, 2007}}</ref> * 9:26 a.m.: E-mails were sent to campus staff, faculty, and students informing them of a "shooting incident" at the West AJ dormitory.<ref name=WashPost.33Dead>{{cite news | last = Pierre | first = Robert | last2 = Horwitz |first2 = Sari |last3=Spinner |first3=Jackie |title=33 Dead in Virginia Tech Shootings, At Least 24 Injured | publisher = [[Washington Post]] |date=April 16, 2007 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/16/AR2007041600533.html?hpid=topnews |accessdate=April 16, 2007}}</ref>[[Image:Virginia Tech massacre Damiano photo from Holden Hall modified2.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Elementary French class students take cover in Holden Hall Room 212]] * Around 9:30 am: A female student walked into Norris 211 and alerted the occupants that a shooting occurred at West Ambler Johnston.<ref name=Goddard/> * 9:42 a.m.: Students in the engineering building, Norris Hall, made a [[9-1-1]] emergency call to alert police that more shots had been fired.<ref name=Mystery/><ref name=WDBJ7.Timeline>[http://wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6378569 Timeline of Virginia Tech Shooting Spree] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070530183103/http://wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6378569 |date=May 30, 2007 }} ''WDBJ7''</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=3078552&page=1 |title=170 Shots, No Motive |first=David |last=Schoetz |date=April 25, 2007}}</ref> * 9:45 a.m.: Police arrived three minutes later and found that Cho had chained all three entrances shut.<ref name=Mystery/> * Between 9:40 and 9:51 am: Using the [[.22 Long Rifle|.22 caliber]] [[Walther P22]] and [[9 mm Luger Parabellum|9 millimeter]] [[Glock 19]] [[handgun]] with 17 magazines of ammunition, Cho shot 47 people, killing 30 of them.<ref name=NYT.Return/> Cho's rampage lasted for approximately nine minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N25225812.htm|title=Thomson Reuters Foundation|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=February 18, 2015}}</ref> A student in Room 205 noticed the time remaining in class shortly before the start of the shootings.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/17/us/20070417_SHOOTING_GRAPHIC.html?ex=1177732800&en=7f033140a028fa2d&ei=5070 | work=The New York Times |title=Deadly Rampage |date=April 17, 2007}}</ref> * Around 9:40 a.m.: Students in Norris 205, while attending Haiyan Cheng's issues in scientific computing class, heard Cho's gunshots. The students, including Zach Petkewicz, barricaded the door and prevented Cho's entry.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/talking_point/6561733.stm | work=BBC News |title=Student describes shooting spree |date=April 16, 2007}}</ref> * 9:50 a.m.: After arriving at Norris Hall, police took 5 minutes to assemble the proper team, clear the area and then break through the doors.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/26/AR2007042600292.html |title=5-Minute Delay Crucial in Tech Shooting |first=Kristen |last=Gelineau |date=April 26, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> They used a shotgun to break through the chained entry doors. Investigators believe that the shotgun blast alerted the gunman to the arrival of the police.<ref name=NYT.Return/> The police heard gunshots as they entered the building. They followed the sounds to the second floor. * 9:50 a.m.: A second e-mail announcing: "A gunman is loose on campus. Stay in buildings until further notice. Stay away from all windows" was sent to all Virginia Tech email addresses. Loudspeakers broadcast a similar message.<ref name=WDBJ7.Timeline/> *9:51 a.m.: As the police reached the second floor, the gunshots stopped. Cho's shooting spree in Norris Hall lasted 9 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/25/AR2007042502453.html |title=Police: Va. Tech Bloodbath Lasted 9 Min. |first=Kristen |last=Gelineau |date=April 25, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Police officers discovered that after his second round of shooting the occupants of room 211 Norris, the gunman fatally shot himself in the temple.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/04/22/va.tech.autopsies.ap/index.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517020220/http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/04/22/va.tech.autopsies.ap/index.html|title=Medical examiner:Â Cho died from bullet to templeÂ - CNN.com|archivedate=May 17, 2007|publisher=|accessdate=February 18, 2015}}</ref> * 10:17 a.m: A third e-mail was sent to notify about the cancellation of classes and advise people to stay where they are.<ref name=SchoolWarning> [http://www.newsday.com/news/nationworld/nation/am-shooting-email0416,0,2065286.story?page=2&coll=ny-sports-columnists "Students: School's warning came too slow"], ''Newsday.com,'' April 17, 2007.</ref> * 10:52 a.m.: A fourth e-mail was sent to warn of "a multiple shooting with multiple victims in Norris Hall," saying the shooter has been arrested and that police are hunting for a possible second shooter. The entrances to the campus buildings were locked.<ref name=Geelong>[http://www.geelongadvertiser.com.au/article/2007/04/17/2950_news.html "US university shooting: Timeline of events."] ''Geelong Advertiser,'' retrieved on April 16, 2007.</ref> * 12:00 p.m.: At a press conference, authorities said there may have been more than 21 people killed and twenty-eight injured.<ref name=WDBJ.Confirm>[http://www.wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6374823 Virginia Tech Authorities Confirm 20 Fatalities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418003331/http://www.wdbj7.com/Global/story.asp?S=6374823 |date=April 18, 2007 }}, [[WDBJ]], April 16, 2007</ref> * 12:42 p.m.: University President [[Charles Steger]] announced that police were releasing people from buildings and that counseling centers were being set up. * 1:06 p.m.: The death toll had risen to 22. * 1:43 p.m.: News stations confirmed that there were two separate shootings in a two-hour period. * 4:30 p.m.: A university statement confirmed that there had been at least 31 deaths at Norris Hall, including the shooter.<ref>[http://filebox.vt.edu/users/news/Steger_statement_2007-04-16_2.mp3 (mp3)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418191126/http://filebox.vt.edu/users/news/Steger_statement_2007-04-16_2.mp3 |date=April 18, 2007 }}</ref> * 5:31 p.m.: News stations reported that Cho shot himself in the [[face]]. * 7:30 p.m.: A news conference confirmed the number of weapons used, and a possible identification of the suspect that would not be released at that time. * 8:22 p.m.: News stations confirmed that Cho wore a bullet-proof vest. * 9:06 p.m.: Police knocked on the door of Suite 2121, alerting Grewal and informing him that Cho killed the people in Norris and West Ambler Johnston halls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/04/19/Worldandnation/Pop__pop__then_panic.shtml|title=Worldandnation: Pop, pop, then panic|publisher=|accessdate=February 18, 2015}}</ref>
==Aftermath== '''Tuesday, April 17''' * 9:15 a.m.: Virginia Tech Police Department released name of shooter as Cho Seung-Hui and confirmed the death toll of 33.<ref name=VT.Front>{{cite web | publisher = Virginia Tech official website |title=Front page |url=http://www.vt.edu |accessdate=April 16, 2007}}</ref> * 9:30 a.m.: Virginia Tech announced that classes would be cancelled "for the remainder of the week to allow students the time they need to grieve and seek assistance as needed."<ref name=VT.Front/> * 2:00 p.m.: A [[convocation]] ceremony was held at the university community at [[Cassell Coliseum]]. President [[George W. Bush]], First Lady [[Laura Bush]], and Virginia Governor [[Tim Kaine]] were among the many people in attendance. [[Image:2007 Virginia Tech massacre candlelight vigil.jpg|thumb|500px|right|Virginia Tech students mourn their fallen friends at a candlelight vigil.]] * 8:00 p.m.: A candlelight [[vigil]] was held on the University Drillfield.<ref>AP. (April 17, 2007) [http://blog.washingtonpost.com/virginia-tech-shootings/?hpid=topnews Va. Tech Community Mourns at Candlelight Vigil] ''Washington Post''. Accessed April 17, 2007.</ref>
'''Wednesday, April 18''' * 8:25 a.m.: A [[SWAT]] team entered Burruss Hall, a campus building next to Norris Hall. No explanation was immediately available. Virginia Tech's public affairs office stated that police were responding to "suspicious activity".<ref name=BurrussHall>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/04/18/vtech.security.alert/index.html |title=Source: Armed police surround Virginia Tech building|publisher=CNN|accessdate=April 18, 2007}}</ref> * 4:37 p.m.: Local police authorities announced that television network NBC received correspondence from Cho, some of which included images of him holding weapons, writings, audio recordings and videos; this information was immediately submitted to the FBI. Since the package was timestamped between the first incident at West Ambler Johnson and the second shooting at Norris Hall, it is possible some of the material was drafted by Cho during the 2 hour interval.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18169776/ |title=Gunman in massacre contacted NBC News |accessdate=April 19, 2007 |work=MSNBC}}</ref>
'''Thursday, April 19''' * 9:49 a.m.: Virginia Tech announced that all students killed on Monday will be granted posthumous degrees in the field in which they were studying. These degrees would be given to the families at the regular commencement exercises that they would have participated in with their friends.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.com/story/News/2007041927/Virginia-Tech-to-award-victims-posthumous-degrees |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407025518/http://www.dailymail.com/story/News/2007041927/Virginia-Tech-to-award-victims-posthumous-degrees |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 7, 2010 |title=Cho's high school classmate recalls taunts: 'Go back to China' |accessdate=April 19, 2007 |work=Charleston Daily Mail }}</ref>
'''Friday, April 20''' * All Day: VA Governor Kaine declared a statewide day of mourning. Alumni encouraged display of the Virginia Tech school colors: orange and maroon.<ref>(April 20, 2007) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/19/AR2007041902549.html A Statewide Day of Mourning for Virginia Tech] ''Washington Post''. Accessed April 20, 2007.</ref> *Cho's family issues statement of apology.<ref name=FamilyStatement>{{cite news |title=Cho family statement |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/04/20/shooting.family.statement/index.html |work=[[CNN|CNN.com]] |publisher=Time Warner |date=April 20, 2007 |accessdate=April 15, 2008}}</ref>
'''Monday, April 23''' * William Massello, an assistant state medical examiner, said autopsies of Cho's 32 victims revealed that he fired "more than 100" bullets into them. "Some were hit once; some were hit several times, more than once. We had two, three, four, maybe even as high as six." The initial autopsy of the Virginia Tech gunman found no gross brain function abnormalities that could explain the rampage that left 33 people dead.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/22/AR2007042201418.html |title=No Abnormalities Found in Cho's Brain |first=Philip |last=Rucker |first2=Jackie |last2=Spinner |date=April 23, 2007 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
'''June 12, 2007''' * Cho's family allows the release of Cho's records to the Virginia Tech Incident Review Panel.
'''August 30, 2007''' * The Virginia Tech Incident Review Panel completes its report, which is now publicly available.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vtreviewpanel.org/report/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904215714/http://www.vtreviewpanel.org/report/index.html |archivedate=September 4, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

[[File:Trond Bergh.jpg|thumb|upright|Trond Bergh]] '''Trond Bergh''' (born 16 September 1946) is a Norwegian [[economic history|economic historian]], and researcher at the Department of Innovation and Economic Organisation of the [[BI Norwegian Business School]].<ref>[http://www.bi.edu/research/employees/?ansattid=fgl99017 Trond Bergh] at BI Norwegian Business School. Accessed 11 October 2013.</ref>
== Life and work == Bergh was born in [[Tvedestrand]], and took the [[cand.philol.]] degree at the [[University of Oslo]] in 1973.
Bergh was the director of the [[Labour Movement Archive and Library]] from 1989 to 1999, and was then employed at the Centre for Business History and, later at the Department of Innovation and Economic Organisation of [[BI Norwegian Business School]].<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Trond Bergh|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|first=|last=|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/Trond_Bergh|language=Norwegian|accessdate=17 April 2009}}</ref>
With the latter work Bergh became involved in a legal case. Former secretary of the [[Standing Committee on Finance and Economic Affairs]] [[Haakon Bingen]] sued Bergh and Eriksen as well as the publishing house Cappelen Akademiske Forlag, because the second volume of ''Den hemmelige krigen'' contained information that portrayed Bingen as a close friend of communist [[Peder Furubotn]]. In late 1999 the [[Supreme Court of Norway]] found that this was not true, and circulation of the book was forbidden, until the reference to Bingen had been amended. Bingen was also entitled to {{NOK|146,975}} of costs.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bingen vant mot forlag i Høyesterett|agency=Norwegian News Agency|date=2 December 1999|page=6|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
== Publications == Bergh's books on Norwegian economic history include ''Vekst og Velstand'' (1977), ''Norge fra u-land til i-land'' (1983) and ''Foredlet virke: Historien om Borregaard 1889–1989'' (with [[Even Lange]], 1989). He also penned ''Storhetstid 1945–1965'', released 1987 as volume five of ''[[Arbeiderbevegelsens historie i Norge]]'', and in 1998 he released the two-volume history on surveillance in Norway, ''Den hemmelige krigen: overvåking i Norge 1914–1997'' about [[surveillance]] together with [[Knut Einar Eriksen]].<ref name=snl/>
Bergh has also written volume I of the two-volume series from 2004 on the railway history of Norway, ''Jernbanen i Norge 1854–2004'', the first volume covering the period from 1854 to 1940.<ref name=bergh2004>{{cite book|series=Jernbanen i Norge 1854–2004|title=Nye spor og nye muligheter. 1854–1940|first=Trond|last=Bergh |volume=1|language=Norwegian |location=Bergen|publisher=Vigmostad Bjørke|year=2004 |isbn=82-419-0331-6 }}</ref>

[[Image:Annales Veteris Testamenti page 1.jpg|thumb|''Annales Veteris Testamenti'' page 1 (Latin)]] [[Image:Annals of the World page 1.jpg|thumb|''Annals of the World'' page 1 (English)]] The '''Ussher chronology''' is a 17th-century [[chronology]] of the [[history]] of the world [[Biblical literalist chronology|formulated from a literal reading]] of the [[Old Testament]] by [[James Ussher]], the [[Archbishop of Armagh (Church of Ireland)|Archbishop of Armagh]] and [[Primate of All Ireland]]. The chronology is sometimes associated with [[young Earth creationism]], which holds that the Universe was created only a few millennia ago by God as described in the first two chapters of the [[Books of the Bible|biblical book]] of [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]. Ussher fell into disrepute in the 19th century. Published in 1650, the full title of Ussher's work in Latin is ''Annales Veteris Testamenti, a prima mundi origine deducti, una cum rerum Asiaticarum et Aegyptiacarum chronico, a temporis historici principio usque ad Maccabaicorum initia producto'' ("Annals of the Old Testament, deduced from the first origins of the world, the chronicle of Asiatic and Egyptian matters together produced from the beginning of historical time up to the beginnings of [[Maccabees]]"). Ussher's work was his contribution to the long-running theological debate on the age of the [[Earth]]. This was a major concern of many [[Christian]] scholars over the centuries. The chronology is sometimes called the Ussher{{endash}}Lightfoot chronology because [[John Lightfoot]] published a similar chronology in 1642–1644. This, however, is a misnomer, as the chronology is based on Ussher's work alone and not that of Lightfoot. Ussher deduced that the first day of [[Genesis creation narrative|creation]] fell upon, October 23, 4004 BC, in the [[proleptic Julian calendar]], near the [[autumnal equinox]]. Lightfoot similarly deduced that Creation began at nightfall near the autumnal equinox, but in the year 3929 BC. Ussher's proposed date of [[4004 BC]] differed little from [[Dating Creation#Date of Creation according to the Pentateuch|other Biblically-based estimates]], such as those of [[Jose ben Halafta]] (3761 BC), [[Bede]] (3952 BC), Ussher's near-contemporary [[Joseph Justus Scaliger|Scaliger]] (3949 BC), [[Johannes Kepler]] (3992 BC) or [[Sir Isaac Newton]] (c. 4000 BC).{{cite book|author=William W. Hay|title=Experimenting on a Small Planet: A Scholarly Entertainment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=teJYlWH9vg4C&pg=PA63|accessdate=November 17, 2013|year=2012|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783642285608|page=63}} {{Dubious|date=October 2017}} Ussher was influenced by the same account as the [[apocrypha]]l [[Book of Jasher (biblical references)|Book of Jasher]], dating the worldwide flood to 2349 BC and the birth of [[Terah]] in 2127 BC. The date of 4000 BC as the creation of [[Adam]] was at least partially influenced by the widely held belief that the Earth was approximately 5600 years old (2000 to Abraham, 2000 from Abraham to the birth of [[Christ (title)|Christ]], and 1600 years from Christ to Ussher), corresponding to the six days of Creation, on the grounds that "one day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day" ({{bibleverse|2|Peter|3:8|KJV}}). This tradition was believed to indicate that Jesus would return in 2000 AD,{{cite book|author=Kenneth G. C. Newport|title=Apocalypse and millennium: studies in biblical eisegesis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f3Cm9ALJbe0C&pg=PA104|accessdate=23 March 2011|date=28 August 2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-77334-8|page=104}}{{cite book|author1=Christopher Rowland|author2=John Barton|title=Apocalyptic in history and tradition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CrcoAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=23 March 2011|year=2002|publisher=Sheffield Academic Press|isbn=978-0-8264-6208-4|pages=233–252}} more than six thousand years after 4004 BC. Modern proponents of this interpretation hold that the creation date 4004 BC could be inaccurate. ==Ussher's methods== The chronologies of Ussher and other biblical scholars corresponded so closely because they used much the same methodology to calculate key events recorded in the [[Bible]]. Establishing the chronologies is complicated by the fact that the Bible was compiled by different authors over several centuries with lengthy chronological gaps, making it difficult to do a simple totaling of Biblical ages and dates. In his article on Ussher's calendar, James Barr has identified three distinct periods that Ussher and others had to tackle:James Barr, 1984-85. "[https://www.escholar.manchester.ac.uk/api/datastream?publicationPid=uk-ac-man-scw:1m1647&datastreamId=POST-PEER-REVIEW-PUBLISHERS-DOCUMENT.PDF Why the World Was Created in 4004 BC: Archbishop Ussher and Biblical Chronology]", ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester'' '''67:'''603–607. # "''Creation to Abraham's migration.''" This section is fairly easy to calculate, using the chronological data in Genesis 5 and 11, which gives an unbroken male lineage, with dates, from the creation to Abraham being called out of Ur of the Chaldeans. Ussher uses the chronology found in the Masoretic text instead of the alternative chronologies found in the Septuagint and Samaritan Pentateuch. Ussher fixed this period as 2082 years, from 4004 to 1922 BC. # ''"Abraham's migration to Solomon's temple."'' Ussher wrote the time from Abram leaving Haran to the Exodus was 430 years (400 years of persecution, 30 years after left Haran) {{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/AnnalsOfTheWorld/Annals#page/n23/mode/2up|title=Annals of the World|last=Ussher|first=James|publisher=|year=1650|isbn=|location=|pages=23}} {{bibleverse||1 Kings|6|KJV}} gives 480 years from the Exodus to the beginning of Solomon's temple in the fourth year of Solomon's reign. These 910 years span from 1922 to 1012 BC. # ''"Period of the temple laid to the Babylonian captivity."'' This period is the most difficult to calculate, due to repeated difficulties in correlating the regnal years of the kingdoms of Judah and Israel. The simple addition of the reigns of Judah's kings gives 430 years, but by positing a few overlapping reigns, Ussher shortens this to 424 years: 1012 to 588 BC. After reckoning the years from creation to the last kings of Judah, Ussher used {{bibleverse|2 Kings|25:27}} to establish the length of time from the creation to the accession of Babylonian king Amel-Marduk (also known as Evil-Merodach).James Barr, 1984-85. "[https://www.escholar.manchester.ac.uk/api/datastream?publicationPid=uk-ac-man-scw:1m1647&datastreamId=POST-PEER-REVIEW-PUBLISHERS-DOCUMENT.PDF Why the World Was Created in 4004 BC: Archbishop Ussher and Biblical Chronology]", ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester'' '''67:''' 579-580. He then used information from Babylonian, Greek, and Roman sources to fix the date of Amel-Marduk's enthronment at 562 BC (after Nebuchadnezzar's death), from which he was able to deduce a creation in 4004 BC. In fixing the date of Jesus' birth, Ussher took account of an error perpetrated by [[Dionysius Exiguus]], the founder of the [[Anno Domini]] numbering system. Ussher chose 5 BC as Christ's birth year because [[Josephus]] indicated that the death of [[Herod the Great]] occurred in 4 BC.John P. Pratt, [http://www.johnpratt.com/items/docs/herod/herod.html "Yet another eclipse for Herod"], ''The Planetarian'', vol. 19, no. 4, Dec. 1990, pp. 8–14. Thus, for the Gospel of Matthew to be correct, Jesus could not have been born after that date. The season in which Creation occurred was the subject of considerable [[theology|theological]] debate in Ussher's time. Many scholars proposed it had taken place in the spring, the start of the Babylonian, Chaldean and other cultures' chronologies. Others, including Ussher, thought it more likely that it had occurred in the [[autumn]], largely because that season marked the beginning of the Jewish year. Ussher further narrowed down the date by using the [[Hebrew calendar|Jewish calendar]] to establish the "first day" of creation as falling on a Sunday near the autumnal equinox.James Barr, 1984-85. "[https://www.escholar.manchester.ac.uk/api/datastream?publicationPid=uk-ac-man-scw:1m1647&datastreamId=POST-PEER-REVIEW-PUBLISHERS-DOCUMENT.PDF Why the World Was Created in 4004 BC: Archbishop Ussher and Biblical Chronology]", ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester'' '''67:''' 591. The day of the week was a backward calculation from the six days of creation with God resting on the seventh, which in the Jewish calendar is Saturday—hence, Creation began on a Sunday. The astronomical tables that Ussher probably used were [[Johannes Kepler|Kepler]]'s ''Tabulae Rudolphinae'' (''[[Rudolphine Tables]]'', 1627). Using them, he would have concluded that the equinox occurred on Tuesday, October 25, only one day earlier than the traditional day of its creation, on the fourth day of Creation week, Wednesday, along with the Sun, Moon, and stars {{bibleverse||Genesis|1:16|KJV}}. Modern equations place the autumnal equinox of 4004 BC on Sunday, October 23 (by the Julian calendar).[http://emr.cs.iit.edu/home/reingold/calendar-book/Calendrica.html Calendrica] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050216102054/http://emr.cs.iit.edu/home/reingold/calendar-book/Calendrica.html |date=2005-02-16 }} The position of the Sun at the autumnal equinox is 180°, where 0° is its position at the vernal equinox. Ussher's understanding of creation placed the "first day" referred to in {{bibleverse||Genesis|1:5|KJV}} on October 23, but with a "pre-creation" event, which he identified as the "beginning of time" occurring the previous night.James Barr, 1984-85. "[https://www.escholar.manchester.ac.uk/api/datastream?publicationPid=uk-ac-man-scw:1m1647&datastreamId=POST-PEER-REVIEW-PUBLISHERS-DOCUMENT.PDF Why the World Was Created in 4004 BC: Archbishop Ussher and Biblical Chronology]", ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester'' '''67:''' 592. Ussher referred to his dating of creation on the first page of ''Annales'' in Latin and on the first page of its English translation ''Annals of the World'' (1658). In the following extract from the English translation, the phrase "in the year of the Julian Calendar" refers to the Julian Period, of which year 1 is 4713 BC, and therefore year 710 is 4004 BC.
In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. Ge. 1:1 This beginning of time, according to our chronology, happened at the start of the evening preceding the 23rd day of October in the year of the Julian Calendar, 710.
Ussher provides a slightly different time in his "Epistle to the Reader" in his Latin and English works:James Ussher, [https://books.google.com/books?id=VrHER1jYzhIC&pg=PA9 "Epistle to the Reader"], ''Annals of the World'' (2003) page 9. "I deduce that the time from the creation until midnight, January 1, 1 AD was 4003 years, seventy days and six hours." Six hours before midnight would be 6 pm. ==Ussher's chronology today== {{more citations needed|section|date=October 2017}} By the middle of the 19th century, Ussher's chronology came under increasing attack from supporters of [[Uniformitarianism (science)|uniformitarianism]], who argued that Ussher's "young Earth" was incompatible with the increasingly accepted view of an Earth much more ancient than Ussher's. It became generally accepted that the Earth was tens, perhaps even hundreds of millions of years old. Ussher fell into disrepute among [[theology|theologian]]s as well; in 1890, Princeton professor [[William Henry Green]] wrote a highly influential article in ''[[Bibliotheca Sacra]]'' entitled "Primeval Chronology" in which he strongly criticised Ussher. He concluded:
We conclude that the Scriptures furnish no data for a chronological computation prior to the life of Abraham; and that the Mosaic records do not fix and were not intended to fix the precise date either of the Flood or of the creation of the world.[http://www.genevaninstitute.org/syllabus/unit-two-theology-proper/lesson-5-the-decree-of-creation/primeval-chronology-by-dr-william-henry-green/ Primeval Chronology]
The similarly conservative theologian [[B. B. Warfield]] reached the same conclusion in "On The Antiquity and Unity of the Human Race",''Princeton Theological Review'', 1911 commenting that "it is precarious in the highest degree to draw chronological inferences from genealogical tables". Nevertheless, Professor [[James Barr (biblical scholar)|James Barr]] (then Oriel Professor of the interpretation of the Holy Scripture, Oxford University) wrote in 1984:
…probably, so far as I know, there is no professor of Hebrew or Old Testament at any world-class university who does not believe that the writer(s) of Genesis 1–11 intended to convey to their readers the ideas that… the figures contained in the Genesis genealogies provided by simple addition a chronology from the beginning of the world up to later stages in the biblical story…James Barr, Oriel professor of the interpretation of the Holy Scripture, Oxford University, England, in a letter to David C. C. Watson, April 23, 1984.
Archbishop Ussher's chronology has in recent years been subject to artistic criticism, including in the play ''[[Inherit the Wind (play)|Inherit the Wind]]'' (based on the [[Scopes Monkey Trial]]) and the [[fantasy]] novel ''[[Good Omens]]'' which alleges that "he is off by a quarter of an hour". A different viewpoint comes from [[Stephen Jay Gould]], who, while totally disagreeing with Ussher's chronology, nevertheless wrote:{{cite journal |url = http://www.stephenjaygould.org/library/gould_house-ussher.html | title = Fall in the House of Ussher | author = [[Stephen Jay Gould]] | journal = Natural History | volume = 100 |date = November 1991 | pages = 12–21 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120303202324/http://www.stephenjaygould.org/library/gould_house-ussher.html | archivedate = March 3, 2012}}
I shall be defending Ussher's chronology as an honorable effort for its time and arguing that our usual ridicule only records a lamentable small-mindedness based on mistaken use of present criteria to judge a distant and different past
Ussher represented the best of scholarship in his time. He was part of a substantial research tradition, a large community of intellectuals working toward a common goal under an accepted methodology…
